title: In your opinion, what is or isn't ok?
body:
I'm legitimately curious. It's obvious how some of the more vocal players on boards feel, but I'd like to know how more of you guys feel about this stuff. It should only take a minute.

{{sticker:vlad-salute}}

replies.body:
I felt like that entire thing was dumb.
Isn't the problem just riots bot is too stupid to understand context.

> Isn't the problem just riots bot is too stupid to understand context.

While the automated systems don't (or, rather, can't) always understand context, there's more to the issue than that. For example (and directly relating to this issue), part of the problem is the varying opinions of players on what kinds of behaviours are/aren't acceptable. There's so many different variations of that that it can be hard to nail down an "across the board" "behavioural line" that reflects the opinions of the overall community.

> [{quoted}](name=HeartVine,realm=OCE,application-id=T8eq2lFQ,discussion-id=EdgAzNQh,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2017-12-23T13:54:56.781+0000)
>
> While the automated systems don't (or, rather, can't) always understand context, there's more to the issue than that. For example (and directly relating to this issue), part of the problem is the varying opinions of players on what kinds of behaviours are/aren't acceptable. There's so many different variations of that that it can be hard to nail down an "across the board" "behavioural line" that reflects the opinions of the overall community.

"Tribunal"
you know, THE SHIT WE USE TO HAVE?
before an automated bot who cannot understand context auto bans people for talking to friends, OR doesn't ban people when they know how to get around the system.

Tribunal didn't work as well as it felt. Tribunal gives players a lot more agency, which is obviously a good thing, but players voting on tribunal ended up being very harsh, it was almost like a vengeance thing. As a result it required a whole lot of review which Riot just didn't have the manpower for.

It's a lot easier to review the occasional appealed case from the automated system than almost every case from tribunal. It may not feel so good for players, but it gets things done a lot faster with a lot more accuracy.

>It's a lot easier to review the occasional appealed case from the automated system than almost every case from tribunal.

"it's a lot easier to pretend the bot is working then to pretend the tribunal is working"

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}} 

>but it gets things done a lot faster with a lot more accuracy.

Except it doesn't, because again as we have discussed previously, we went from what the Community decided on as a whole of those who used tribunal, to what the "community" of people that report "want", which the bot can't really determine, because it doesn't understand context.

A false positive or too harsh punishment here and there is a lot easier to review that having to review almost every case. If every case has to be checked anyway it sort of defeats the purpose of having that system doesn't it?

But here is the thing, do you think anyone in the community thinks that these instant 14 day bans for one word is actually accurate?

If no, then you can see that the bot has been failing in it's job for the past few months.

If you do, then your very possibly a minority of the community, and are just having the system manipulated to what you want because of poor manipulation of the system by Riot by making reports be the only way we can effect and decide what is/isn't ok.

Of the ones that have actually posted logs, most of them *are* accurate. There are plenty of arguments for having a lesser ban, or longer escalation to perma, but I don't think there's all that many people that believe a punishment of some sort was undeserved in the vast majority of these cases.

In recent memory I've seen one chat log that struck me as probably being a false positive. The rest were all either edited, not posted or deserved (the severity argument aside), so where then is all this failure?
I'm saying the severity IS the failure, and it's happening constantly, to a large amount of those that are getting banned, when we have Chat restrictions for a reason.

There is an argument there, and I'll admit from what you've posted that wasn't the impression I was really getting from you. I believe most of the cases I've seen to be worth more than a chat restriction, but I agree that for some putting them one step before perma is harsh.

This has less to do with whether you think the punishment is worth, and whether you think reform can happen.

Lots of these people have been playing for years with the same attitude, because the system is terrible, and doesn't actually pick up these actions for a long time (unless you believe that all these banned accounts that have 3+ year histories turned into assholes over night)

The punishment system, in Riot Lyte's own words, was meant to help players reform, not focus on giving out punishment's.

EDIT: and sorry if it was unclear, but yes the severity of punishments is just terrible, fact is, saying one word should never lead to an instant 14 days.

Sorry for the late reply, I've been out for Christmas, and if I make less sense than usual I'm hella sick so again, sorry bout that.

I suppose my side of the argument would be where do you draw the line between "try to reform them" and "they are creating serious problems stop them from affecting other players".

To use an example of something you despise, if someone is constantly creating a new account to intent feed every time they get banned, the goal shifts from reform to stopping them from hurting other players right?

But that's only an example of what I mean, I understand these aren't cases of people creating new accounts to keep being toxic.

I guess where I stand on this, is that allowing hate speech or things like KYS perpetuates that it's ok, regardless of the actual intent with which it is said. It might be a joke, but especially in a game with some pretty young kids, it creates a culture. Which to an extent is fine within the confines of the game, but it doesn't end there and that's the problem.

That said, I agree with you to an extent. I believe the no tolerance terms they have chosen are appropriately serious, and I believe that the severity of that should be reflected in the punishment, however I agree with you that one offence shouldn't put someone one step away from perma.

The cases I've seen I think pretty much all of them are deserved, and I think 14 days is a good amount of time because it's long enough to impress severity and short enough that it is not simply forgotten for half of it. If there was a second 14 day tier for this kind of offence before perma I think that would be ideal because it doesn't much undermine the severity, but it does give an opportunity for reform for the people who haven't been taking it seriously.

I think we'll have to agree to disagree on how bad we think the words themselves are, but that's nothing new, I would press you to remember that this game is rated 13+ though.

The biggest thing I think for Riot is ultimately communication, something which they very often spectacularly fail at. If they're going to take a no tolerance stance on some behaviours, then announce that, so the people with different views understand that they either compromise and keep it to out of game comms, or stop the behaviour all together. 

There also needs to be clearer communication on the appeals process. People often seem to think they can only appeal to remove a ban, despite the fact they can just as easily appeal the length of it as well.

>I guess where I stand on this, is that allowing hate speech or things like KYS perpetuates that it's ok, regardless of the actual intent with which it is said. It might be a joke, but especially in a game with some pretty young kids, it creates a culture. Which to an extent is fine within the confines of the game, but it doesn't end there and that's the problem.

The thing is, if this was dealt with in the first place with chat bans, we wouldn't have gotten to a point where this is ok (as in, most of the community believes what they are saying IS ok, and hell you can tell that by the people who come in here thinking their attitude is ok with really bad chat logs.).

You need to start with chat bans and let the community know it's not ok, not just give them a big F you and expect them to reform off that.

>If they're going to take a no tolerance stance on some behaviours, then announce that

I do have to agree with this, stop pussy footing around and not announcing it because "people will avoid using the bad words that we can recognise" because that just isn't a valid excuse (because it happens anyway, and it just means that Riot would have to also shift with the offensive words that people start saying.).

Communication is Riot's biggest downfall as far as I'm concerned, and it's nothing new either. A lot of the stuff that people get real riled up about could have been solved by being open about their direction and then being visibly open to feedback.

I'm of the mind they take more of what they're players say into account than it seems (remembering that the main team is in NA and that there are some very vocal minorities) but they don't broadcast it at all. If the community has driven a change they need to actually make it known.

In terms of gaining an understanding of the behaviours the overall community thinks isn't acceptable, the Tribunal is a good concept, *however* in terms of actually dealing with that behaviour (which was one of the main functions of the Tribunal as it was), is extremely inefficient. That's why Riot chose to take it down.

If we're talking about systems that are actually implemented in the current state of the game, there's literally nothing beyond reports that give Riot any indication of what behaviours player think are and aren't acceptable. Bringing back a system as inefficient as the Tribunal isn't going to help anything at this point (unless it doesn't actually deal with the behaviours in question, which would be counter-intuitive to having it in the first place).
Define inefficient, because to me it feels like your throwing around buzz words without any actual understanding of how the system works.

As in, taking several months for punishments to actually be doled out. There's plenty of people who say it's about as bad, or even worse, with the systems that are in-game now, but the Tribunal isn't going to help anything at this point. The game is just too far gone for something like that to work, and that will only change if Riot's values and priorities change.
I replied to Yasai about it, but in short, tribunal voters ended up being very harsh on punishments, which necessitated a lot of review, far more than any appealed bans from the automated system.

The point was to get an understanding of how the community feels about it. I imagine you land in the court of an instant 14 day ban is too harsh, but that isn't true of everyone. I'm more of the mind that things like KYS are never ok to say, regardless of the intent, but that's precisely why I wanted to do this.
Also can we ban that one dude who keeps spamming streamer montages with ethots in player creations. I hate that guy and ppl like that.
I've been out for Christmas but I'll have a look. Thanks for actually reporting it, makes it much easier to find.

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=T8eq2lFQ,discussion-id=EdgAzNQh,comment-id=00080000,timestamp=2017-12-27T00:43:18.929+0000)
>
> I've been out for Christmas but I'll have a look. Thanks for actually reporting it, makes it much easier to find.

I don't know what is or isn't meant to go in player creations but imo cutting a bunch of clips from streamers who aren't you and putting them in a youtube video isn't really creative. Is there an actual guideline to whats allowed on that sub-board?

No super strict guides, though "don’t take credit for someone else’s work" is and always should be a thing. It's not quite the same since it's a highlight reel, but as far as I'm concerned that counts as taking...not credit, but basically straight ripping someone else's work solely to benefit yourself, so no bueno. If he doesn't at least provide credit in his descriptions I will continue to delete.

Many of his thumbnails included mature content too, which is a no no here so that was an easy delete.

Is there even any point to answering this. You have no power do you? For the most part I personally don't care at all what people say in a video game. If you do then your skin is too thin to be online at all.

The guy saying [slur for blacks] in chat isn't stopping me from winning a game. The guy going on about how bad my gank was or w/e isn't stopping me from winning. Meanwhile someone can fill his whole match history with disco nunu without punishment. Someone can choose to afk or give up and receive no punishment. These things actually stop me from winning. These matter much more in my mind.

I know the majority of the internet is in fact mentally weak. They can't handle bad words. So I am not surprised verbal gets you banned nor do I care too much because I can hold my tongue if need be. But even then we have to ask why in game behaviour detection is basically non-existent by comparison when all the verbal abuse in the world can be stopped with one click or by growing a pair.

It's not so much about affecting change, but more getting a wider feel for how the community feels. There is a vocal minority on boards, and I think most people would rather take 2 minutes to answer an anonymous survey than type out an essay on boards.

People are entitled to their opinions, but when faced with effort and possible backlash, a lot of people will choose not to express them. People with your mindset that words don't matter whatever is said are far more likely to ignore the backlash part, so it creates an imbalance.

As for the in game vs chat punishments, I think it comes down to chat being a lot easier to punish. I agree that intent feeding detection really isn't great, but whether or not someone said [racial slur] is a lot easier to determine than "is this person trolling, or just playing an off meta pick badly". There's a careful balance between allowing players the freedom to play what they want, and ensuring that that freedom doesn't hurt other players.

As for the mentally weak argument. Just because you can handle bad words doesn't mean you should have to. Just because someone's abuse doesn't bother you, shouldn't make it ok to abuse you. It's not a simple problem, and there isn't a simple solution.

what the fuck is targeted swearing when compared to casual swearing (eg saying fuck you, is that casual?)?

What threats are we talking?

Racial slurs without or with negative context, so in other words every context?

Your form is basically invalid from the start, because you don't actually define what any of this shit is.

EDIT: And also, context is key for all this shit, and you provide none of it, and the bot can't detect it.

> what the fuck is targeted swearing when compared to casual swearing (eg saying fuck you, is that casual?)?

I'd say casual swearing is things like "f\*ck me", "what the f\*ck" or "f\*cking hell" etc, while targeted swearing is things more like "f\*ck you", "get f\*cked" and "go f\*ck yourself" etc.

> What threats are we talking?

Probably any kind of threat that could be taken seriously, ranging from threatening to feed to threats on a persons life (though I feel it may have been better to separate them).
 
> Racial slurs without or with negative context, so in other words every context?

From what I understand, it's more like "Racial slurs without (or with negative) context". The grammar in that question was lacking, in my opinion.
 
> Your form is basically invalid from the start, because you don't actually define what any of this shit is.

Agreed. Some kind of "key" defining each term used (even if they're defined, such as via examples, when used) would be a great improvement. Makes it very clear to people what is actually being asked.

>I'd say casual swearing is things like "f*ck me", "what the f*ck" or "f*cking hell" etc, while targeted swearing is things more like "f*ck you", "get f*cked" and "go f*ck yourself" etc.

I mean the issue is, that "targeted" swearing is so broad that it goes from "fuck you" (what i would consider ok) to going off the handle to the point i probably shouldn't attempt typing it on the boards.

>Probably any kind of threat that could be taken seriously, ranging from threatening to feed to threats on a persons life (though I feel it may have been better to separate them).

Which again, ranges from what might be acceptable (what if i threaten to camp an enemy? is that ok?) to what isn't acceptable (threatening to come to someone's house and beat the shit out of them.)

>From what I understand, it's more like "Racial slurs without (or with negative) context". The grammar in that question was lacking, in my opinion.

But again we run into something that isn't determinable, because it's too broad "fucking %%%%%%" might be ok with regards to talking about a lucian for example, but then there is pure racism that isn't ok.

>Agreed. Some kind of "key" defining each term used (even if they're defined, such as via examples, when used) would be a great improvement. Makes it very clear to people what is actually being asked.

I mean, these questions all need to have context, which again, is the key to all of this, asking is "x" behaviour ok? is different to asking if someone saying "fuck you" is ok.

All of it comes down to context.

You're both right, I could have been clearer. Admittedly it was somewhat of a rush job, I was only after a general feel but I should have been more specific. Still, you could always state your issue without all the aggression. I was trying to keep it concise so it wouldn't be so long that people wouldn't bother.

You can assume what is and isn't ok just by figuring out which people are casual and which people are triggered by words. Nothing can be said for me to report someone for swearing. The only thing I ever report someone for is hindering my game experience making me lose the game. But this is where the problem lies, whether or not the chat is monitored by a bot or the community, the result will be the same. Fedora wearers of the game who take their power too seriously and decide to punish anyone who says a bad word or even remotely sounds negative will go to this system. Comparable to that one kid in school who's a teachers pet and tells on you if you do something wrong. 

It's not going to be run by people like us that do not care about the chat. If I had to judge a person just because they had an argument with someone, no punishment will come about no matter what was said. As long as there was no trolling at all from either of them then there's no punishment. Games, especially in an official setting, are full of these 'teachers pet' type people who want to win the praise of the game. 

To anyone not wanting a punishment - mute everyone or hide the chat. You will never receive a punishment if you do them. That's what I have done because this game is full of people who get triggered over small things and report you.

To use your teacher's pet analogy, there are degrees of behaviour. Like the difference between telling on someone for copying their homework (which pretty much everyone has done at least once) or telling on someone who just beat up a black kid cause they didn't like the way they looked.

But the point of the survey was precisely to get a good spread of opinions, so if you filled it out then thanks.

The only behavior that should be punishable is behavior that negatively affects the game. Any sort of verbal punishment should not exist. There is a mute button and if someone doesn't wanna use it and doesn't like what someone says then that's their problem, not the other guys. I wouldn't compare someone beating someone else up as bad in severity to anything in this game, not even intentionally feeding. Racism is the only thing I can remotely think of being punishable but even then, there's a mute button, use it. I've got a thick skin so I couldn't care less about what anyone says, racist or not, but the carebears are different and almost every game caters towards them cause 'muh feelings'


I filled out the survey but you can probably guess what I picked.

I don't give a fuck about anyone swearing in game, but I take racism seriously (and I'm white).

The only chat abuse I report is racism, in-game behaviour is far worse.
I filled it out, and although I don't differentiate between 'casual' and 'directed' racism, I still think poor in-game behaviour is more negative than anything said in chat.
Agreed.
A mindset I don't understand, but that's the point of this. Thanks for the input.

The thing is you dont have to understand it, the vast majority of the community (or atleast the vocal ones) agree that ingame behaviour is more damaging than a few bad words.

sticks and stones mate. sticks and stones.

I can mute/block douchebags in chat, I can't block myself from playing with in-game trolls. That's my issue.
Idgaf what anyone says, I can just mute them, but if they intentionally feed or otherwise play in a style that is harmful to their own team, I have no way of avoiding them in the future.
Very true, imo only the real serious chat offences are worse than in game stuff since as you say, we have a means to stop it, but there are some things that really just go way too far.
Oh, and for research value Seras, my original account was permabanned on NA (before OCE existed), and I reformed and have never had a ban since.
This is good to hear :)

Ive filled it out as best I can. ^^
I hope the collective results provide some interesting thought.

Although I doubt your curiosity will be sated, sometimes seeing the results raises even more questions.
True, it was more general anyway, but hopefully it can give some sort of impression.
I answered with as much of my opinion as I could, I hope you take it into consideration and understand where I'm coming from.
That's what I'm hoping :)
